meaning_mnemonic:
Something with an <kanji>arrange</kanji>d <kanji>nature</kanji> must be very <vocabulary>orderly</vocabulary>. Nicely arranged, very tidy and orderly!

Note that for this word, you need to add と to the end to make it an adverb, and たる to make it an adjective! It's quite formal, so you'll mostly just see it in literature to describe something that's been arranged in an orderly way.

A <kanji>bad</kanji> <kanji>example</kanji> is a <vocabulary>bad example</vocabulary> and is something you don't want.

This is a formal expression and less common than 悪い例 (bad example) or 良くない例 (not good example).

The kanji means <kanji>wound</kanji>, and this verb is transitive, so it means <vocabulary>to damage something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to injure something</vocabulary>.

You can use it to talk about parts of your body, so you'll sometimes see it used interchangeably with 痛める. The difference is that it's objectively focussing on the damage, not the pain. That's why 傷める can be used for objects like cars and furniture, too, whereas 痛める is only for people and body parts.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
うなぎ means "eel," so うなぎ丼 is an eel <kanji>rice bowl</kanji>, aka an <vocabulary>eel bowl</vocabulary>. And yes, it's very good.

This very common food is <kanji>parent</kanji> and <kanji>child</kanji> <kanji>rice bowl</kanji>, aka a <vocabulary>parent and child rice bowl</vocabulary>. The parent is a chicken. The child is an egg. This can also be called <vocabulary>chicken and egg rice bowl</vocabulary>, or simply <vocabulary>oyako-don</vocabulary>.
This <kanji>throw up</kanji> <kanji>energy</kanji> you feel inside of you… could it be… <vocabulary>nausea</vocabulary>?!

If 吐く is to throw up, and if 出す is to remove or hand over, then if you throw up and hand that throw up over to someone via your throwing up, you are going <vocabulary>to spit out</vocabulary> at them, or <vocabulary>to spew out</vocabulary>, or something gross along those lines. Then again, this word can be used to be like "spit the info out already!" too, so it's not all spitting for reals.
If a 奴 is just some dude or some guy, adding a ら on there makes it plural. Now it's <vocabulary>those dudes</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>those guys</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>mouth</kanji> <kanji>deep red</kanji> is a deep red you put on your mouth. This is <vocabulary>lipstick</vocabulary>.

If 薦める is "to recommend," then the noun version would be a <vocabulary>recommendation</vocabulary> or some <vocabulary>advice</vocabulary>. This generally refers to a recommendation of a person or thing, not an action.

If 勤める is "to be employed at," then the noun version of this is <vocabulary>work</vocabulary>. I mean, I really hope you're doing work at the place that employed you... if not you'll probably be fired.
A 磁場 is a "magnetic field." An <kanji>electricity</kanji> version of this is an <vocabulary>electromagnetic field</vocabulary>.

放射 is "radiation." Add the <kanji>ability</kanji> of radiation and you have <vocabulary>radioactivity</vocabulary>, for some reason. I guess things don't have radioactivity until you have given them the ability of radiation, right?

If 指揮 is "command" or "lead" then <kanji>someone</kanji> who does those things is a <vocabulary>commander</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>conductor</vocabulary>. Usually the kind that conducts an orchestra!
Remember 源氏? He has his own 物語. This is the very first novel ever written (that we know about). This is the <vocabulary>Tale of Genji</vocabulary>.
If 損害 is "damage" then the verb version would be <vocabulary>to damage</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>branch</kanji> <kanji>bean</kanji> doesn't mean a whole lot this way, but you probably know the food that this describes anyways. This is <vocabulary>edamame</vocabulary>, a food made from <vocabulary>steamed soybeans</vocabulary>, usually with a bit of salt added for flavor.
<kanji>Bean</kanji> <kanji>rot</kanji> is when you take soy beans, let them ferment, and then you make <vocabulary>tofu</vocabulary> out of them! Yep, that's what tofu is. Rotten beans.

Your <kanji>former</kanji> <kanji>surname</kanji> is just that: your <vocabulary>former surname</vocabulary>! This is often your <vocabulary>maiden name</vocabulary>, as in the name you had before getting married.
<kanji>Restore</kanji> to the <kanji>former</kanji> self. This is <vocabulary>restoration</vocabulary>.
Your <kanji>surname</kanji> and your <kanji>name</kanji> put together create your <vocabulary>full name</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Trade</kanji> is <kanji>easy</kanji> if you like <vocabulary>trade</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>commerce</vocabulary>.
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>sweet</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>sweet</vocabulary>.

When you <kanji>see</kanji> something as <kanji>sweet</kanji>, you're just looking at it like it's some little sweet kid with sweet flavoring. You are not taking it seriously, or you are taking it lightly. So sweet! That's why this word is <vocabulary>to not take seriously</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to take lightly</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>sweet</kanji> <kanji>group</kanji> is a group of people who love sweet things. They really have quite the <vocabulary>sweet tooth</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>commander</kanji> will <kanji>come</kanji> in the <vocabulary>future</vocabulary>. Not anytime soon, but in the future.

将来 generally implies the nearer, more concrete future. You’ll probably use it when discussing your career plans or a company's growth strategy, and not what the Earth will be like 100 years from now.

The <kanji>commander</kanji> of the <kanji>army</kanji> is the <vocabulary>shogun</vocabulary>. Do you know the shogun? He ran Japan, and was like the ruling general over the states. You can also call him the <vocabulary>general</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>commander</vocabulary>, if you like.

The <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>commander</kanji> is the <vocabulary>general</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>admiral</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>head</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>leader</vocabulary>). Basically, they're big stuff.

The <kanji>master</kanji> <kanji>commander</kanji> is the <vocabulary>commander</vocabulary> of all commanders, the <vocabulary>commander in chief</vocabulary> if you will... or, even the <vocabulary>team captain</vocabulary>.
We are of the <kanji>same</kanji> <kanji>alliance</kanji>. We are in an <vocabulary>alliance</vocabulary>.

If we <kanji>take along</kanji> our <kanji>alliance</kanji> and move it forward to something better, we have a <vocabulary>league</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>federation</vocabulary>. It's like we're one group now!

An <kanji>alliance</kanji> <kanji>promise</kanji> is one that's made with a <vocabulary>pledge</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>pact</vocabulary>. Imagine making an alliance with someone, pledging your support.
If you <kanji>leave behind</kanji> <kanji>property</kanji> it's known as your <vocabulary>inheritance</vocabulary>.
The thing we <kanji>leave behind</kanji> at a <kanji>fault</kanji> is a <vocabulary>loss</vocabulary>.
What I <kanji>leave behind</kanji> and <kanji>transmit</kanji> to you is your <vocabulary>heredity</vocabulary>. You have my genes, even after I'm gone.
You <kanji>leave behind</kanji> your <kanji>body</kanji> to join the spirit realm. This body remainder is your <vocabulary>corpse</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>remains</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>stretch</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to grow longer</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be stretched</vocabulary>. It's often used figuratively, in which case you'll translate it as <vocabulary>to make progress</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to increase</vocabulary>.

You know this is version where you aren't doing the stretching, it just kinda happens, because it's just like how your stomach stretches when you drink beer (びる). Its capacity just seems to increase so you can take in more and more beer.
A <kanji>debt</kanji> <kanji>ticket</kanji> is a <vocabulary>bond</vocabulary>. You buy it from the government and then they pay it back to you with interest... in theory.

Your <kanji>debt</kanji> <kanji>rights</kanji> state that you have a certain amount of <vocabulary>credit</vocabulary> with your bank. And if they try to say you don't have that credit you can file a <vocabulary>claim</vocabulary> against them!
A <kanji>country</kanji>'s <kanji>debt</kanji> is the <vocabulary>national debt</vocabulary>. It can also be <vocabulary>bonds</vocabulary>, like the ones you buy from your country.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>reach</kanji> and the verb version is <vocabulary>to reach</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to amount to</vocabulary> . This is like "x reached y" or "x amounted to y."

When something <kanji>reach</kanji>es <kanji>normal</kanji>, it has finished <vocabulary>diffusion</vocabulary>. Normal things aren't all bunched up and concentrated. Normal things are spread out nice and evenly, via diffusion.

I <kanji>reach</kanji>ed the <kanji>ordinal number prefix</kanji> that represents a passing score on my test. This means I was able to <vocabulary>make the grade</vocabulary>! Wow, <vocabulary>passing an exam</vocabulary> feels great.

及第 is an old-fashioned term that you might see as part of the word 及第点 (a passing grade), especially if you read a lot of classic Japanese books.
<kanji>Nara</kanji> is <kanji>good</kanji> and it is <vocabulary>Nara</vocabulary> (the place, we're talking about).
The <kanji>god</kanji> <kanji>Nara</kanji> <kanji>river</kanji> <kanji>Prefecture</kanji> is <vocabulary>Kanagawa Prefecture</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
It is <kanji>obsolete</kanji> so we must <kanji>stop</kanji> it. No more of it anymore. This is <vocabulary>abolition</vocabulary>.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>obsolete</kanji> and this word means <vocabulary>to become obsolete</vocabulary>.

Something that will <kanji>exchange</kanji> <kanji>energy</kanji> is something that pulls in air, takes out the bad stuff, and then outputs good air, exchanging it for the bad. That is <vocabulary>ventilation</vocabulary>.

If you <kanji>change</kanji> something then <kanji>exchange</kanji> it, you are making a <vocabulary>conversion</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>change</vocabulary>.

変換 generally refers to converting something from one form to another, like data conversion, energy transformation, or even converting hiragana to kanji.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>pluck</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to pluck</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to pick</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to prune</vocabulary>, like with plants.

Take your <kanji>finger</kanji> and <kanji>pluck</kanji> out the one thing out of all the things that needs <vocabulary>pointing out</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>identification</vocabulary>. Yep, that's the one. Pluck that one.

To <kanji>pluck</kanji> off someone's mask and <kanji>departure</kanji> it off somewhere away from their face, that is <vocabulary>to unmask</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to expose</vocabulary> someone.

The kanji and the word are the same. That means they share meanings as well. This word can also mean <vocabulary>core</vocabulary> because that's where the nucleus is in a cell, and <vocabulary>nuclear</vocabulary> because we like to blow ourselves up nowadays...
<kanji>Nucleus</kanji> arms (兵器), aka weapons, are <vocabulary>nuclear weapons</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>nucleus</kanji> experiment (実験) is a <vocabulary>nuclear test</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>open sea</kanji> is where the sea <kanji>join</kanji>s together to be the <vocabulary>open sea</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

<kanji>Rope</kanji> <kanji>writing</kanji> was used during the <vocabulary>Jomon</vocabulary> period, a time in <vocabulary>ancient Japanese</vocabulary> history when people decorated pottery with rope.

A <kanji>harbor</kanji> <kanji>wave</kanji> is a wave big enough, it could easily submerge an entire harbor. What could you call such a wave? Perhaps a <vocabulary>tsunami</vocabulary>, or a <vocabulary>tidal wave</vocabulary>.
I would like to <kanji>offer</kanji> my <kanji>blood</kanji> to someone else in the form of a <vocabulary>blood donation</vocabulary>.
I'd like to <kanji>offer</kanji> <kanji>money</kanji>, no strings attached. It's free. It's a <vocabulary>donation</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>medicine</kanji> can <kanji>heal</kanji>. This is <vocabulary>medical treatment</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Cure</kanji> and <kanji>heal</kanji> me. That is <vocabulary>medical therapy</vocabulary>.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>inherit</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to inherit</vocabulary>.

I will <kanji>inherit</kanji> at your <kanji>consent</kanji>. It's not just given straight to me at birth, though it kind of is. I get <vocabulary>succession</vocabulary>, but only if people say it's okay.
<kanji>Maintain</kanji> what we have and put it on <kanji>hold</kanji>. We need to keep it up to date and fixed, so we need <vocabulary>maintenance</vocabulary>.

We must <kanji>maintain</kanji> the <kanji>new</kanji> and get rid of the old. It's time for a <vocabulary>restoration</vocabulary> of policy! This also refers to the <vocabulary>Meiji Restoration</vocabulary> too. In fact, it probably mostly refers to this, though you'll learn a more full version of this later.

A <kanji>dance</kanji> <kanji>machine</kanji> isn't really a machine... a 台 is a large machine thing counter, so in this case it's talking about a stage. A dancing stage is a <vocabulary>stage</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>dance</kanji> and the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to dance</vocabulary>, as well as <vocabulary>to flutter</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>song</kanji> <kanji>dance</kanji> <kanji>deed</kanji> is a deed you do that involves singing and dancing. This is the traditional form of stage deeds, known as <vocabulary>kabuki</vocabulary>. Watch it on YouTube if you want a taste.
You <kanji>dance</kanji>, you <kanji>step</kanji>, you dance, you step. Good job! Now you're doing <vocabulary>dancing</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>step</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to step on</vocabulary>. So, not quite "to step" like you might expect, but at least you're stepping still, though it's on something.
<kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>generally</kanji> does things... in <vocabulary>general</vocabulary>. It's more <vocabulary>common</vocabulary> this way.
This has the same meaning as the kanji. Stick this onto another word and you have "ultra _____."
Something that is <kanji>ultra</kanji> natural (自然的) is <vocabulary>supernatural</vocabulary>. Too natural! Super!
A <kanji>super</kanji> <kanji>sound</kanji> that's <kanji>fast</kanji> is <vocabulary>supersonic speed</vocabulary>.
An <kanji>ultra</kanji> <kanji>sound</kanji> <kanji>wave</kanji> is an <vocabulary>ultrasonic wave</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>trust</kanji>, but the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to ask for</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to rely on</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to request</vocabulary>. When you trust someone you can 頼む them, but only when you trust them. You put it in their hands. You trust them, after all.
I <kanji>believe</kanji> I can <kanji>trust</kanji> you. That's why I put so much <vocabulary>reliance</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>trust</vocabulary> on you to do well.
I am <kanji>reliant</kanji> on you and I <kanji>trust</kanji> you. Therefore, I have a <vocabulary>request</vocabulary> for you that I'd like to <vocabulary>entrust</vocabulary> you with.
Being <kanji>reliant</kanji> on something in order to <kanji>exist</kanji> is <vocabulary>dependence</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>reliance</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>horse</kanji> <kanji>deer</kanji> is a <vocabulary>stupid</vocabulary> idea. You're an <vocabulary>idiot</vocabulary> for thinking about it, really. It's quite <vocabulary>dumb</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>deer</kanji> <kanji>child</kanji> <kanji>island</kanji> <kanji>prefecture</kanji> is <vocabulary>Kagoshima Prefecture</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
You have my <kanji>consent</kanji> and <kanji>agreement</kanji>. This is my <vocabulary>consent</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>agreement</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>acceptance</vocabulary>.
I will <kanji>accept</kanji> and I have <kanji>agreement</kanji> in the matter. I have come to <vocabulary>acceptance</vocabulary>.
I will <kanji>permit</kanji> this, and you have my <kanji>agreement</kanji>. Both of these things combine to be my <vocabulary>permission</vocabulary> and my <vocabulary>consent</vocabulary>.
Do we have <kanji>agreement</kanji> or <kanji>no</kanji>? Which is it? <vocabulary>consent or refusal</vocabulary>? <vocabulary>Yes or no</vocabulary>? Choose!
An <kanji>elephant</kanji> <kanji>tusk</kanji> is the material known as <vocabulary>ivory</vocabulary> (or just an <vocabulary>elephant tusk</vocabulary>).
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
降参 is "surrender" so the verb version would be <vocabulary>to surrender</vocabulary>.

The kanji is <kanji>exchange</kanji>, so this verb is <vocabulary>to exchange</vocabulary>. If you exchange one thing for another thing, you are going <vocabulary>to exchange</vocabulary> it, after all. This word refers to exchanging one thing for something different.

Wondering about the difference between 替える and 換える? 替える means swapping one thing for another of the same kind, whereas 換える means exchanging or trading one thing for something different, often of similar value. So, you use 替える when switching out light bulbs, but opt for 換える when trading jewelry for cash.

A <kanji>sick</kanji> <kanji>bed</kanji> is a <vocabulary>sickbed</vocabulary>. If you're in that bed, you're probably sick.

病床 is a relatively advanced word found in written phrases like 病床にふす (to be in sickbed). It can also formally refer to a <vocabulary>hospital bed</vocabulary>.

This is the adjective form of 汚, which is <kanji>dirty</kanji>. This word is the adjective <vocabulary>dirty</vocabulary>, but you can also use it to say things like <vocabulary>filthy</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>foul</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>unclean</vocabulary>.

Something <kanji>big</kanji> in <kanji>width</kanji> is <vocabulary>large</vocabulary>. In fact, it's of a pretty <vocabulary>substantial</vocabulary> size. This word is used to describe a large magnitude or degree of change, increase, decrease, or difference in a given situation.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
This is the noun version of the kanji <kanji>mistake</kanji>, so it means a <vocabulary>mistake</vocabulary> or if it's on a computer, an <vocabulary>error</vocabulary>.
Remember how you learned that 貴重 means "valuable?" Well valuable <kanji>product</kanji>s are your <vocabulary>valuables</vocabulary>!

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>pickle</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to pickle something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to marinate something</vocabulary>.

漬ける is specifically used to describe the process of pickling or marinating foods, such as vegetables, fish, or meat.
An <kanji>uncle</kanji> feels like a <kanji>father</kanji> sometimes, but he's still an <vocabulary>uncle</vocabulary> after all.
An <kanji>aunt</kanji> feels like a <kanji>mother</kanji> sometimes, but she's still an <vocabulary>aunt</vocabulary> after all.

The kanji itself means <kanji>well up</kanji>, and this is also <vocabulary>to well up</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to gush out</vocabulary>.

Remember us talking about courage welling up in the kanji mnemonic? This word can also be used for that kind of figurative welling up, like of emotions, which is where the meaning <vocabulary>to arise</vocabulary> comes from.

<kanji>Well up</kanji> <kanji>water</kanji> is <vocabulary>spring water</vocabulary>. Kind of makes sense, right? 

Note that 湧水 is a formal word generally encountered in written language.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

A <kanji>same</kanji> <kanji>window</kanji> <kanji>meeting</kanji> is a meeting with people who spent a long time gazing out of the same classroom window as you. Who are those people? They're your former classmates, and this is a <vocabulary>class reunion</vocabulary>. It can also mean <vocabulary>alumni association</vocabulary>, which is still something you do with former classmates, so it makes sense.

Do you know how <kanji>suspicious</kanji> <kanji>I</kanji> get if I have an <vocabulary>injury</vocabulary>? I start suspecting everyone around me of having given me the injury. It was you, wasn't it?
This is the verb version of the kanji <kanji>fry</kanji>, so it means <vocabulary>to fry</vocabulary>, more specifically <vocabulary>to stir-fry</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to sauté</vocabulary>.

<kanji>Tooth</kanji> <kanji>science</kanji> gives you the science of <vocabulary>dentistry</vocabulary>, simple as that!

Note that when used by itself, this word solely refers to the scientific field of dentistry. You'll often see it used in combination with other medical words, so have a look at the common word combinations if you wanna know more!
